New Records: Freddie Freeman's walk-off grand slam in game one was the first in World Series history.
Freddie Freeman's home run in game three was his fifth in five straight World Series games, tying the all-time series record set by George Springer.
Key Match Events: Freddie Freeman hit a walk-off grand slam in the tenth inning of game one, leading the Dodgers to a 6-3 victory.
Yoshinobu Yamamoto pitched 6.1 innings of one-hit baseball in game two, contributing to the Dodgers' 4-2 win.
Walker Buehler threw five shutout innings in game three, maintaining a 0.50 ERA in three World Series starts.
Alex Verdugo hit a two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth inning of game three, but it was not enough to overcome the Dodgers' lead.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers dedicated game one to the memory of Fernando Valenzuela, who passed away just days before the series started.
Post-Match Reflections: There will be ongoing discussions about Aaron Boone's decision to pitch Nestor Cortez in game one, which led to Freddie Freeman's historic walk-off grand slam.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers are wearing a number 34 patch with Fernando Valenzuela's first name throughout the World Series to honor his memory.
